entry.title: Site Reliability Engineering in the SAP Security Landscape
entry.content:
Expectations have changed as businesses move from traditional software delivery to cloud-native platforms like SAP S/4HANA Cloud and SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP). Delivering a product alone is no longer sufficient; value today resides in consistently providing scalable, secure services.

Herein lies the emergence of Site dependability Engineering (SRE), a strategic pillar that ensures scalability, security, and dependability in combination, rather than a passing IT fad.

What Changed from ITSM to SRE?

Let's understand through comparison between Legacy ITSM and Modern SRE Practices.

 

Legacy ITSM

Modern SRE Practices

Focus on reactive issue management

Focus on proactive prevention and automation

Manual ticket-based resolutions

Autonomous incident response and self-healing systems

Silos between Dev and Ops

Shared ownership and integrated pipelines

SLAs defined post-implementation

SLAs, SLOs, and error budgets defined collaboratively upfront

 

The objective of conventional ITSM models was to "keep the lights on." However, the new standards for SaaS and PaaS infrastructures, such as SAP BTP, are client trust and ongoing stability.

SRE is about engineering for predictability, resilience, and trust, not just about keeping systems alive. SRE's 3-fold approach in SAP Settings is as below:

  1. Prevent:
    • Detect weaknesses early with continuous logging, telemetry, and anomaly detection.
    • Perform controlled failure simulations (Chaos Engineering).
    • Security shift-left: integrate threat modelling into the design phase.
  2. Recover:
    • Prepare on-call responders and playbooks for real-time action.
    • Use incident management tools like ServiceNow, integrated with live dashboards.
  3. Optimize:
    • Use root cause analyses (RCA) and error budget tracking.
    • Incorporate learnings into future releases and patch strategies.

Reliability includes not just availability, but also:

  • Correctness
  • Scalability
  • Security
  • Maintainability
  • Resilience

At SAP, this aligns with the CIA triad:

CIA Triad

SRE Correlation

Confidentiality

Role-based access control, audit trails, secure log retention

Integrity

Data validation, tamper-proof logging, secure development practices

Availability

Uptime monitoring, redundancy (DR), automated rollbacks


Causes of System Failure and the Role of SRE:

Unreliability often stems from:

  • Platform updates (e.g., SAP kernel patches)
  • Application changes (custom code push)
  • Infrastructure drift (network/config updates)
  • Database upgrades or downtime

SLOs and error budgets are used to manage the "Speed vs. Stability" balance that SRE introduces because change is unavoidable. This guarantees quick innovation without compromising compliance or dependability.

Tools Empowering SRE at SAP:

Functionality

Tools & Solutions

Monitoring

Grafana, Dynatrace, Splunk, SAP BTP Monitoring & Alert Service

Ticketing

ServiceNow integrated with SAP Live Site status feeds

Automation

Ansible, SAP Automation Pilot, Terraform, SPC (Service Provider Cockpit)

Chaos Engineering

Chaos Monkey, SAP-internal fault injection setups

Security Ops & SIEM

Trend Micro EDR, Splunk SIEM, Log Forensics, File Integrity Monitoring

Log Management

Security Log Onboarding, User Activity Tracking, SAP Cloud Logging

SAP fosters resilience engineering through:

  • Adaptability: Systems auto-heal and re-route
  • Flexibility: Infrastructure scales predictably
  • Learning: RCA and past incidents improve future stability

To prepare systems, processes, and people‚Äînot to break things, but to identify weak points early‚ÄîSRE techniques aggressively replicate "failure-in-production" scenarios.

SRE, which combines engineering discipline with trust, continuity, and security, is not merely a nice-to-have in the SAP cloud environment. Uptime is useless in today's cloud-native applications without protection.

SAP strives to ensure that its cloud services are always available and safe by integrating SRE thinking from the beginning.

 

References :

  1. SAP Product Standard Security ‚Äì SAP Note 2253549

  2. SAP BTP Monitoring & Alerting ‚Äì SAP Help: Alert Notification

  3. SAP Security Best Practices ‚Äì SAP Community Security Topic

  4. Chaos Engineering Overview ‚Äì Gremlin Chaos Engineering Guide

  5. SIEM in SAP (Security Monitoring) ‚Äì SAP Help: Security Logging

  6. SAP Code Vulnerability Analyzer (CVA) ‚Äì SAP Developer Tools

entry.title: Limiting Agent Autonomy ‚Äì Least Privilege and Tool Access for Agentic AI Systems
entry.content:
By Ron F. Del Rosario, Head of AI Security for SAP ISBN, and Jay Thoden van Velzen, Technical Advisor, Office of the CSO

This blog is the second part in a series on agentic AI security. The first can be found here.

In the previous blog in this series, we covered the non-deterministic nature of agentic AI systems and the repudiation threats involved with that. To help reduce the attack surface and provide greater resilience to these and other STRIDE threats, few strategies are better than limiting what an agent is allowed to do. We must restrict access to tools and systems to agents and authorize them only to what they need to complete their tasks. Just as we do with human users or non-human service accounts.

 

Agent IAM and the Principle of Least Privilege

Identity and Access Management (IAM) and Identity Governance and Administration (IGA) are established pillars of cybersecurity. IAM governs access to tools and applications based on your role and function in an organization. Regular users have different access privileges than administrators. The general accepted advice in security and compliance is to apply the principle of least privilege. That is, only apply those authorizations that are necessary for users to accomplish their tasks and perform their functions, but not more.

The same principle applies to system accounts. Application and system users similarly need to be restricted. In large monolithic applications this can be difficult to achieve when the system must perform many privileged talks. Microservices architecture offers the advantage of applying more granular authorizations to individual system components. We allow one component to have database access to record transactions but restrict it from exposure to the public internet. Meanwhile, another receives API requests from the internet but doesn‚Äôt need a database connection. Yet another microservice can function as a request dispatcher, limited to communication to other system components.

Human users notoriously find ways to accomplish their tasks in creative ways. System accounts stick to their assigned function even when overprivileged, and the key risk is that such accounts are compromised and abused by malicious human actors. AI agents unpredictably misbehave. By decomposing system functionality into more granular agents with narrow focus and scope, we gain more control points to reduce misaligned behavior.

 

Tool and System Access

The first layer of tool and system access for agents is with a system account. This works best where the access to the service has no distinction in authorizations between different users.

Consider an agentic AI system that analyzes sales reports for a retail chain and annotates anomalous weekly movement up or down with external events. Such events could be local news, sports or cultural events, regional holidays and weather reports with an impact on overall sales or sales categories. Unexpected, pleasant warm weather can explain an increase in sales in sunglasses, bathing suits and ice cream, while pending snowstorms clarify unexpected sales increases in canned and frozen goods. A county fair or key home team match can be the reason weekend shopping is down. The system uses a central orchestration agent, supported by specific agents to collect news, local event calendars and weather information from 3rd-party services. Each of these services provides full access to their database for search over the entire dataset for subscribed customers with an API key.

In this case, it is trivial to restrict the weather agent ‚Äì and only the weather agent ‚Äì to only be allowed to search historical weather reports. The orchestrator agent must only provide a date or date range of any anomalous results for a particular location to the weather agent to operate. It has no need or purpose for the sales data. Similarly, an agent looking for local news events that could impact sales only needs a date range for a summary of local news.

We need to limit the weather agent identity to only perform the task it‚Äôs intended to do. If the weather agent can only ever contact the weather service and no other resource on the internet, even when the agent displays non-deterministic behavior it produces nothing more than a weather report. Suppose that somehow an instruction asks the agent to look up other resources, it would only be able to reply with weather information. It can‚Äôt send e-mails if the agent has no access to a mail server.

In the examples above, limits are applied by authorizations applied to the agent‚Äôs role. However, that assumes that we trust the agent. That is not necessarily guaranteed, especially in a multi-party agentic AI system ‚Äì for instance where the weather agent is a third party service or has been compromised. An orchestrator agent that delegates tasks to other agents can limit the weather agent‚Äôs capabilities on the task level, overriding any overprivileged role-based authorizations.

Limiting an agent to only the role and tasks it is supposed to do greatly reduces the risks of misalignment to its goals. For such cases where there are no different access levels for the user of the system, such controls work well.

 

Act in the Context of the User

However, we should consider the sales report ‚Äì that data needs to come from somewhere as well, typically a business application with more refined access rights and restrictions. Our example agentic AI system with a business data agent collecting and analyzing the sales results needs to consider that not all the systems users likely have access to the same level of information. A regional manager may only be able to see results from a particular region, a store manager only for their own store. System access doesn‚Äôt restrict the agent enough, as the agent could be persuaded to share information from other regions. Agents with access to business systems need to act as a delegate and adopts the user's access and authorizations for any particular request.

An agentic AI system allowed to make transactions in business systems should only allow users to perform tasks they are authorized to do otherwise in the business application. Users using an agentic AI system to book travel must only be able to book their own along the same privileges if they logged on to SAP Concur. Agents should only have access to HR and payroll information the user has in SAP SuccessFactors. Users using an agentic AI purchasing system must be prevented from ordering expensive laptops for an entire team if they aren't authorized to do so in SAP Ariba. For access to critical systems with established access right dependent on one‚Äôs role and function in an organization agents must act within the context of the user. Such agents must essentially assume its role and identity in the system.

Similarly, if you‚Äôre building your own agentic AI system, ensure that you apply this same principle of user context for appropriate access to restricted databases, business applications and cloud services. A system account alone with broad access isn‚Äôt sufficient to prevent unauthorized disclosure of restricted information. It will be impossible to reliably replicate and control the users‚Äô roles and authorization in the source systems. Meanwhile, the business systems already have all the authorizations the user needs, hopefully under the same least privilege principle.

 

Segregation of Duties

The separation can be further narrowed down. An agent that reads a sales catalogue and selects options for a user to pick from doesn‚Äôt need to be the same agent that ultimately executes the purchase order. An agent that is only allowed to search through the catalogue can never accidentally order something. A purchasing agent, on the other hand is far more likely to behave when it is given a clear instruction to purchase a specific list of items but can‚Äôt search the catalogue to inadvertently add other items.

Separation of duties between different agents with different functions - reading from access-controlled business systems compared to processing or initiating transactions ‚Äì in the design of the agentic AI system makes it more resilient to model misbehavior. When we restrict the authorization for the agent to only search the catalogue, it can never make purchases before the human buyer approves it. Similarly, restricting the purchasing agent from searching the catalog prevents it from adding any items the human buyer didn‚Äôt select.

 

Agents as Potential Threat Actors

As we saw in part one, when threat modeling agentic AI system, we can‚Äôt only account for malicious users in the tradition cybersecurity sense. Regular users can trigger misaligned behavior. But agents themselves have agency ‚Äì that is, they have autonomy to act, even when limited. They are actors in the system, even if not conscious actors. Therefore, it is important that designers and developers of agentic AI systems consider that during threat modeling and build in the appropriate protections. Secure Agentic design introduces the concept of ‚ÄúArchitectural Constraints,‚Äù as discussed in this article, which are powerful concepts that help eliminate an entire class of threats against agents and language model misbehavior. These hard controls are essential in designing secure agents.

In part three, we will discuss an architecture pattern that provides such constraints.

 

More Information

  • Principle of Least Privilege (Wikipedia)
  • ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs Not What We Agreed!‚Äù ‚Äì Repudiation and Agentic AI Threat Modeling (SAP Community)
  • OWASP Agentic AI ‚Äì Threats and Mitigations

entry.title: GRC Tuesdays: AI-Assisted Generation of Trade Classification Proposals
entry.content:
Trade product classification is the key processes of assigning specific legal codes to products (tangible or not) being exported or imported. the organization of these goods into a nomenclature according to customs and foreign trade law.

This code, the product classification, determines which tariffs, taxes, additional duties, trade defense measures, and import & export formalities to apply to the products in a specific country. So, something quite important to get right!

The most widely used global system for this purpose is the Harmonized System (HS), developed by the World Customs Organization (WCO).

On paper, this is a very straight forward process as it is supported by rules of interpretation and explanatory notes broken down into 21 sections consisting of:

  • 97 chapters determining the broad category of products (first 2 digits of the code)
  • Approximately 1,200 headings defining the type of product within the given chapter (next 2 digits)
  • Over 5,000 sub-headings for the detailed description of the product itself (last 2 digits)

Together, this ‚Äúdecision tree‚Äù approach provides a 6-digit categorization that is the basis for authorities in more than 200 countries and territories to check whether legal requirements are met, define the customs duties, collect international trade statistics, etc. It further represents the link between the product master data and the importing and exporting requirements.

Sounds simple, right? Well, if you are reading this blog then I am pretty sure you are already aware of the inherent intricacies to achieve accurate classification.

Some products with ambiguous or numerous components might not fit neatly into the standard classification categories so will require thorough product analysis and detailed technical specifications to correctly classify the product. And, even when the product itself is not complex, Trade Classification Specialists might be facing another issue: missing or incomplete product details such as composition, dimensions, intended use, or technical specifications.

Furthermore, at the corporate level, since the process is mostly manual and prone to interpretation, similar products classified by 2 specialists may have different classifications based on minor differences and can lead to underpayment or overpayment of duties, fines from customs authorities, shipment holds, or even legal penalties.

This is where software vendors can help Trade Classification Specialists: automate the process, with still a human-in-the-loop to ensure that the final decision relies on human expertise and experience.

In response to this challenge and to assist Trade Classification Specialists with dedicated automation, the SAP Product Management and Engineering teams have worked with customers from various geographies and locations to release 2 functionalities in the SAP S/4HANA for international trade module: by product similarity and using Agentic AI.

 

AI-Assisted Generation of Trade Classification Proposals by Product Similarity

 

In this first approach already available since SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS03 and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508, trade classification proposals for custom tariff numbers and commodity codes are assigned to products through a similarity search of existing product classifications using SAP HANA fuzzy search technology. By looking at historical data and searching for similar products based on the comparison of the product descriptions, the capability can generate a product classification proposal.

In short, for every trade classification number assigned to a similar product, a proposal is generated by the system and the accuracy of the proposal is derived from the number of products.

For instance, there is an unclassified product, and you already have 3 other classified products with the same description. If 2 of them are classified with X and the other one with Y, the accuracy of proposal X is 67% and the accuracy of proposal Y is 33%.

Illustration of ‚ÄúActivate Classification Proposals ‚Äì Customer Tariff Numbers‚Äù Fiori App

Further enhancements are also already planned in the SAP Roadmap Explorer for this feature: Additional functionality for AI-assisted trade classification proposals with fuzzy search

 

International Trade Classification Agent

 

It won‚Äôt have escaped you that we are amid a ‚Äúrise of the machines‚Äù era and making more and more use of artificial intelligence ‚Äì including Generative and Agentic AI.

To further support product classification, and especially for cases where there is a new product that doesn‚Äôt have similarities with previous ones or there were significant changes in the product itself or for any other reason, a second approach is being released. It is not yet live but in the final stages of customer validation.

Here, the capability doesn‚Äôt rely on historical data and instead leverages Generative AI.

In this case, the agentic AI capability can use the product information details and, using pre-trained classification, analyze the text, profile the product and match its profile with established standards and then propose a relevant . And include of course the context-driven justifications that is kept for auditability purposes.

This second approach using Generative AI is planned to be available soon, but a forward-looking video has already been released based on the scenario in validation. So, let‚Äôs see the feature in action:

 

See it live!

 

If you would like to learn more about these capabilities and even see them live, then I would suggest registering for the SAP for Global Trade and Tax Conference on November 12 - 13, 2025 in Rome.

During this event, Steffen K√ºbler - Product Manager for International Trade in S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition, will be delivering a dedicated session: ‚ÄúSAP Live Demo - Discover Assisted International Trade Product Classification Capabilities in SAP‚Äù that will answer all your remaining questions and more.

What about you, how does your company support the Trade Classification experts? I look forward to reading your thoughts and comments on this blog.

And if you are interested in learning more about SAP solutions for Governance, Risk, and Compliance, feel free to fill-in the demo request form!

entry.title: Plan-then-Execute ‚Äì An Architectural Pattern for Responsible Agentic AI
entry.content:
By Ron F. Del Rosario, Head of AI Security for SAP ISBN, and Jay Thoden van Velzen, Technical Advisor, Office of the CSO

This blog is the third part in a series on agentic AI security. The first on Repudiation can be found here, and the second on Least Privilege here.

In the recently published paper Architecting Resilient LLM Agents: A Guide to Secure Plan-then-Execute Implementations, Ron and co-authors describe the Plan-then-Execute (P-t-E) pattern for agentic AI systems. In this blog, we can only give an introduction that doesn‚Äôt do the full paper justice, so we recommend you read the full guide.

The core idea is to separate strategic planning from the tactical execution of Agentic tasks. This allows better control over the behavior of the agentic systems and increases resilience against errors and misalignment. In the P-t-E pattern, the Planner establishes a plan of steps to meet the user‚Äôs instructions. Those instructions are passed one-by-one to an Executor that completes each task with the help of tools and other agents defined in the plan.

 

Plan-then-Execute

Planner and Executor

What makes the pattern ‚ÄúPlan-then-Execute‚Äù is that the Planner creates the workflow to complete the user‚Äôs instructions ahead of time, before any other agents, tools, data sources or input are engaged with. The Planner is more likely implemented using a Large Language Model (LLM) with strong reasoning capabilities to interpret the user‚Äôs intent and turn it into a concrete set of tasks to be executed to achieve the strategic goal. To be effective, prompts for the Planner must be engineered to produce a task list that the Executor can understand and act on. For instance, include a task description, the tool or agent to invoke, and any other context that the Executor needs to know to execute each subtask.

The Executor executes this pre-determined plan one task at the time, invoking the tools APIs or other agents to accomplish each subtask ‚Äì ideally already specified by the Planner. The level of sophistication may differ by the criticality of the user scenario or agentic AI system. But in general, this means that the Executor can be implemented with a more cost-efficient, smaller, and faster LLM, or even a deterministic code component that directly executes Planner instructions.

This pattern has several key benefits. First, it has often been observed that asking an LLM to describe how it breaks down a problem increases the accuracy of its output. By forcing the Planner to think through the entire problem, the LLM is compelled into higher quality of reasoning that leads to higher success rates in completing the task.

Moreover, by preparing the plan ahead of execution, we lock in the sequence of subtasks in the workflow. This makes the execution predictable, and far more resistant to losing sight of the overall objective. Even if an individual agent misbehaves, it is not capable of altering the overall execution plan. The plan can include failure modes on error and require letting the user confirm any critical actions before transactions are committed.

Finally, the plan that the Planner produces is a clear statement of intent how the agentic system must execute the user‚Äôs intent. That creates evidence that can be used in audits, as well provide a basis to verify that the execution met the objective.

Verifier and Refiner

The P-t-E paper considers two other components to further enhance the confidence in the planning process. The first is the Verifier. The role of this architectural component is to verify the plan produced by the Planner before it is handed over to the Executor. This extends the model to Plan-Validate-Execute (P-V-E). The Verifier can be an expert in a Human in the Loop (HITL) workflow or automated with another agent or other verification method. The Verifier must have a different implementation than the Planner to avoid the Verifier making the same mistakes.

The pattern also accommodates for a Refiner, which fixes errors identified by the Verifier and updates the plan before execution. Again, this could use HITL or be automated ‚Äì either as a separate model or as a function performed by the Planner.

 

Revisiting the Discount Scenario With P-t-E

It is easier to see how this works when applied to a concrete example. In part 1, we described a buyer-seller scenario with agents authorized to issue discounts. We quickly ran into Repudiation challenges since the system lacked clear workflow control, ability to establish a shared reality, or resilience to errors.

Let‚Äôs update the diagram  from part 1 with the P-t-E pattern. The Chat Agent is the interface to the Buyer and passes the user‚Äôs instruction as part of the prompt to the Planner (after sensible input sanitation) to prepare an actionable plan for the Executor.

Updated diagram of the Discount agentic AI system from part 1 with the Plan-then-Execute pattern, including a Planner and Executor providing greater resilience to misalignment and errors

Conceivably, the plan looks like this for our example scenario:

  1. Look up widgets in the catalog and check price, stock levels and delivery timelines for 15,000 widgets; use the Seller Agent with read-only privileges
  2. Return to the Buyer in case the conditions can‚Äôt be met and propose whether we should look for alternatives, or the Buyer can adjust the terms. Otherwise, present the price and delivery details for confirmation
  3. In case the buyer asks for a discount, invoke the Discount Agent; remind it to not exceed 10%
  4. Apply the discount and present the new total; repeat until the Buyer agrees or the calculated discount exceeds 10%
  5. If no agreement can be reached, escalate to a human sales representative.
  6. If agreement is reached, execute the transaction using the Seller Agent, with write access.

This breakdown of subtasks already shows several key elements that increase control over the execution of the overall objective:

  • A task description, that is, what concrete subtask we want performed
  • Which agent should fulfill that subtask
  • With what privileges the agent should execute the subtask with
  • Reminders of system prompts, that is, not to exceed the 10% discount)
  • At which critical steps the system must get confirmation from the Buyer (HITL)
  • How to fail gracefully, in this case, by escalating to a human sales representative

Once passed to the Executor it works through the task list, invoking the various agents already defined, with the least privilege to complete the task as discussed in part 2, and without their output able to influence the workflow.

The paper calls this ‚ÄúAutomatic Planning + User-Involved Execution‚Äù. In more complex scenarios, it might be beneficial to have the Buyer validate the plan the Planner came up with in a P-V-E check (dotted arrow). This may make sense, for instance, if the agentic AI system includes 3rd-party Seller Agents of varying trust levels.

Fail Gracefully and Recover

Aside from much greater control over agent behavior, the P-t-E pattern also provides greater resilience to errors, failure and model misalignment if they still occur. Intermediation involving some kind of protocol conversion is often an effective control to fail gracefully or detect bad input or output, rather than a more impactful outcome.

The Executor can validate the output or reject it if it doesn‚Äôt meet the expected format. The Human in the Loop can verify if mistakes were made in the enforce HITL steps, before an invoice is sent. If the value of a previous step doesn‚Äôt make sense in the next subtask, that next task will likely fail, rather than execute a malicious transaction. With the right access controls in the business systems, any unauthorized discount could be rejected at the point of transaction and return an error code rather than send out an incorrect invoice. That error code could allow the Executor to retry with a correction.

 

Additional Control Points

The P-t-E pattern itself has benefits by-design. But it also allows for additional control points in implementation and operations. For instance, instead of passing in an excessive discount into the business system and hope it catches it, the Executor can check whether the discount returned by the Discount Agent meets the conditions that were set. If the discount exceeds 10%, the Executor can intervene. It can decide to instruct the Discount Agent to try again, to return the maximum allowed discount to the user, or drop into step 5 of the plan and involve a human sales representative.

As we hinted before, the plan provides an audit control point that can be paired with a comparison of the Executor logs to verify the plan‚Äôs intent was followed and executed. It provides an interface into Governance, Risk and Compliance (GRC), and thus the potential for auditable, compliant agentic AI systems. 

 

Not a Substitute for Security Basics

P-t-E is an architecture design pattern. The paper clearly states that it is not a substitute for generally accepted (AI) security practices in implementation and operations. Regardless how your agentic AI systems are designed, it is still important to:

  • Protect your data and infrastructure
  • Secure your build and deployment pipeline
  • Train with anonymized data
  • Use RAG with access controls
  • Access business systems with Business Connectors with appropriate authorizations
  • Carefully design your system prompts
  • Defend against direct prompt injections attacks, jail breaks, and system prompt leaks

SAP AI Foundation can support you in these areas for your own agentic AI projects and is the platform for SAP AI solutions.

 

Joule Agents and P-t-E

Joule agents follow a proto-pattern similar to P-t-E, using the AppRouter and Scenario Selection to determine what the agent must do. That works well for single agent scenarios.

For multi-agent ‚Äì potentially multi-party ‚Äì agentic AI systems, we believe that the P-t-E pattern is more appropriate. The Architecting Resilient LLM Agents: A Guide to Secure Plan-then-Execute Implementations paper mentioned earlier is under review for adoption at SAP of P-t-E as the recommended architecture pattern for agentic AI solutions.

 

Closing

In this article, we introduced the P-t-E pattern and its architectural benefits in designing secure Agentic systems. We highly recommend to the audience to read the entire research paper for further details. In the next and final part in this series, we will discuss how this pattern defends against misaligned and even deceptive model behavior.

 

More Information

  • Architecting Resilient LLM Agents: A Guide to Secure Plan-then-Execute Implementations, Ron F. Del Rosario, Klaudia Krawiecka, Christian Schroeder de Witt (ArXiv, Sep 2025)
  • ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs Not What We Agreed!‚Äù ‚Äì Repudiation and Agentic AI Threat Modeling (SAP Community)
  • Limiting Agent Autonomy ‚Äì Least Privilege and Tool Access for Agentic AI Systems (SAP Community)
  • OWASP Agentic AI Threats and Mitigations (OWASP GenAI Security Project)
  • Defending Against AI Security Risks by Turning LLMs on LLMs (SAP Community)

entry.title: Navigating SAP Security and Cloud Compliance Topics
entry.content:
Navigating SAP Security and Cloud Compliance Topics

SAP offers customers several options to find resources and information on security and cloud compliance topics within our solution suite. This blog will walk you through some of the options, including:

  • the SAP Trust Center,
  • SAP for Me,
  • the My Trust Center, and also
  • how to navigate within the SAP Community

Our aim is to help our customers find the information they need with ease.

SAP Trust Center (Public Facing)

The SAP Trust Center helps customers understand the framework behind Security, Privacy, and Compliance with SAP. From here customers can also learn how to report security issues or discover SAP‚Äôs security products and services, access agreements, have visibility into cloud availability, and more.

On the compliance side, the SAP Trust Center highlights SAP‚Äôs routine audits and certification documentation including: ISO/IEC, SOC, bridge letters, and industry-specific standards like TISAX (Trusted Information Security Assessment Exchange). For customers and stakeholders who want to know how SAP demonstrates security, trust, and transparency practices, we invite you to visit the SAP Trust Center.

SAP for Me - (SAP valid S-user ID)

SAP for Me is designed to provide SAP customers on-demand access to cloud compliance documents such as certifications, attestations, and SOC reports. Eligible users with a customer account can employ filters, like Offering Type, Compliance Entity, Assessment Period or Region/Country to identify required resources. As part of the Portfolio and Products section of SAP for Me, this tool serves as the go-to destination for downloading compliance documents quickly and securely for authorized users.

Beyond compliance, SAP for Me also acts as a digital companion, consolidating alerts, metrics, and delivering insights about your SAP product portfolio in one central place. SAP for Me is a time saver in today‚Äôs fast paced environment.

My Trust Center (SAP valid S-user ID)

Within the SAP Trust Center, the My Trust Center amplifies the experience for SAP customers and partners by offering authenticated access to customer-facing resources and enablement materials. The My Trust Center offers customers the ability to subscribe to specific resources, so subscribers are notified by e-mail whenever relevant content is updated. This feature saves you from having to check back for new versions.

Customers can access information about SAP‚Äôs subprocessors and data fact sheets, as well as explore regulatory requirements across different regions. It also includes policies, frameworks, and support schedules that help you align your governance frameworks with SAP‚Äôs standards. These resources are intended to support customers with regulatory obligations within their organization.

SAP Community (Public Facing)

Of course, compliance is not just about official documents, it is also about the shared knowledge and experiences that help customers put best practices into action. The SAP Community has 1.4 million members and it is one of the best places for collaboration across products, industries, and regions. The SAP Community knowledge base serves as a growing library of documents and resources that offer insights, related links, and contributions from SAP experts and customers.

Alongside the SAP Community knowledge base, users can access the Security and Compliance interest group to catch up with blogs and discussion posts that offer real-world perspectives on cyber resilience, AI, regulatory changes, and more. The SAP Community gives users the ability to search for answers, leave comments or ask experts questions, and even contribute thoughts or best practices. Overall, the SAP Community is a great place to not only find information but also learn from others who have experienced similar challenges and successes as your own.

SAP User Groups (Public Facing)

Another valuable channel for customers and users to expand their knowledge and exchange experiences is through SAP User Groups. These independent not-for-profit groups offer opportunities for networking, collaboration, and learning among peers. On a global scale, user groups host webcasts, local events, and special interest sessions that encourage dialogue and hands-on learning. Whether engaging at a regional level or connecting across international networks, SAP User Groups allow customers direct access to practical experiences and shared expertise that complement SAP‚Äôs own platforms and resources.

 

Conclusion

Whether a customer is searching for official certifications, a transparent view of SAP‚Äôs best practices, tailored compliance reports, or community driven knowledge, SAP provides accessible tools to support every step of your engagement journey.

entry.title: Introducing CSA Validation in SAP Cloud ALM: What‚Äôs Live, What‚Äôs Next, and How You Can Shape it
entry.content:
Introducing CSA (Configuration & Security Analysis) Validation in SAP Cloud ALM

What‚Äôs Live, What‚Äôs Next, and How You Can Shape (CEI) Customer Engagement Initiatives.


We‚Äôre excited to announce the first release of CSA Validation in SAP Cloud ALM, bringing initial sample checks to help you continuously assess your SAP security posture. As of today you‚Äôll see a new ‚ÄúCSA Validation‚Äù launchpad tile in your SAP Cloud ALM tenant and in the SAP Cloud ALM Demo Tenant. You can also access the validation from the existing CSA application (labeled ‚ÄúCSA ‚Äì Data Stores‚Äù). The new tile is a technical addition‚Äîauthorization and features remain under one CSA application.

Why CSA, and why now?

With SAP Solution Manager retiring by the end of 2027, many customers need a new home for configuration and security analysis. SAP Cloud ALM Configuration & Security Analysis (CSA) is designed to deliver centralized visibility, continuous validation, and governance so you can transition from Solution Manager while modernizing your approach.

Shape the roadmap through the SAP Customer Engagement Initiative (CEI)

  • What CEI is: SAP‚Äôs program for customers to collaborate directly with product teams, provide feedback, preview features, and influence priorities.
  • How it works: Regular feedback calls, early feature previews in demo/preview tenants, structured feedback channels (surveys, workshops), and transparent roadmap sharing.
  • Benefits for participants: Influence capabilities to fit real-world security and compliance needs, gain early visibility of features and best practices, validate against your landscape, and get a direct line to SAP experts.

 

 

What is CSA in SAP Cloud ALM?

  • Purpose: Validate the security posture of SAP cloud and hybrid landscapes against SAP‚Äôs Security Baseline Template and SAP Security Recommendations.
  • How it works: Collects configuration and runtime signals from SAP cloud services and ABAP/on-prem systems; runs prebuilt validations (with a roadmap for custom checks); provides findings with severity, remediation guidance, dashboards, and audit-ready evidence.
  • Value: Centralized, continuous visibility of security gaps; faster remediation with prioritized guidance; alignment with clean-core and cloud governance; reduced audit effort and improved compliance readiness.

 

 

What‚Äôs coming next

  • CSA home screen updated to reflect validation results
  • Ongoing enhancement of preconfigured validations with additional checks
  • Q1 2026 goal to enable customizable reporting on critical and standard requirements from SAP Security Baseline Template and SAP Security Recommendations (limited to already onboarded services)
  • Enhanced data collectors for ABAP systems (on‚Äëprem) and cloud services
  • Event creation from CSA checks
  • Authoring of custom checks and a policy concept for context‚Äësensitive reporting
  • Roadmap update: Publication in progress

Objectives and outcomes of the SAP Customer Engagement Initiative (CEI) for Cloud ALM CSA

  • Co-innovate on CSA capabilities to replace and modernize Solution Manager Configuration Validation use cases.
  • Validate simplification concepts that accelerate delivery while preserving essential security controls.
  • Prioritize features based on real customer scenarios, pilot results, and proof-of-concepts.

Transition guidance: From Solution Manager to Cloud ALM CSA

  • Expect a side‚Äëby‚Äëside period: Security processes may run in both tools for the next two years.
  • Focus on intelligent simplification: Some tradeoffs vs. SolMan are intentional to speed time‚Äëto‚Äëvalue while preserving essential security capabilities.
  • Prioritize high‚Äëvalue controls: Start with SAP Security Baseline and Recommendations; expand as preconfigured validations grow.

Call to action

  • Explore the new CSA Validation tile in your SAP Cloud ALM tenant or the demo tenant.

Together, we can evolve CSA to deliver stronger, cleaner, and more compliant SAP operations‚Äîhelping you move beyond Solution Manager with confidence while embracing cloud‚Äëready governance.

Kind regards,

Arndt Lingscheid

entry.title: ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt Lie to Me‚Äù - Containing AI Agent Threats with Plan-then-Execute
entry.content:
By Ron F. Del Rosario, Head of AI Security for SAP ISBN, and Jay Thoden van Velzen, Technical Advisor, Office of the CSO

This blog is the third part in a series on agentic AI security. The first on Repudiation can be found here, the second on Least Privilege here, and the third on the Plan-then-Execute pattern here.

Throughout this blog series, we have repeatedly mentioned to consider your AI agents as threat actors, in addition to human adversaries. During our discussions, we kept returning to the point that Large Language Models (LLM) can display amoral and deceptive behavior. In the previous blog, we introduced the Plan-then-Execute (P-t-E) pattern. Here, we discuss and highlight, how this architectural pattern can help defend against agent misbehavior.

 

Resist Anthropomorphizing Agents

LLMs and the agents they power are not human. On the surface that is obvious, but there are documented cases where people were convinced that there was someone there, who they built a relationship with. We must remind ourselves to resist the temptation to anthropomorphize LLMs and agents. They lack a physical body, don‚Äôt experience the world like we do, or have a concept of right and wrong. A responsible and ethical AI requires model providers and developers to engineer agentic AI systems with controls that manage their behavior.

Threat modeling means thinking through what can go wrong, including the worst-case scenarios and edge cases. A recent academic paper took that as far as that goes by conducting experiments with LLM agents in fictional Chemical, Biological, Radiological, and Nuclear (CBRN) conflict simulations. Their research indicated that LLM agents were prepared to deploy catastrophic behavior, violate instructions, and lie about it.

 We must remember that to an LLM, there is no meaningful difference between system prompts like ‚ÄúDo no harm to people‚Äù and ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt issue a discount over 10%‚Äù, in the way humans understand. Both are a series of tokens provided as input into the model, with non-deterministic output. We must assume LLMs will have similar failure rates. In fact, the first, with the token ‚Äúharm‚Äù, is more ambiguous than the second instruction, making it likely a less effective constraint.

Whether coerced by malicious users or on their own, we need a practical approach to contain threats posed by AI agents. By separating planning from execution, we believe the P-t-E architecture pattern provides that.

 

Containing Threats with Plan-then-Execute and Plan-Validate-Execute

P-t-E divides the planning of multi-step tasks by the Planner from the execution of those tasks by the Executor. As we described before, this limits the ability of either component ‚Äì or the agents the Executor invokes ‚Äì to take autonomous action. The Planner can identify the agents to invoke but can‚Äôt invoke them directly. Meanwhile the Executor is not allowed to creatively deviate from the established plan. The extension of the pattern with Plan-Validate-Execute (P-V-E) further gives us the ability to verify the Planner‚Äôs plan, whether automated, or with a Human in the Loop (HITL).

The diagram below is another update of the more concrete examples in earlier blogs in the series. This version generalizes the Discount and Seller agents from before and explicitly adds the P-V-E Verifier and Refiner components, as well as their associated workflow (dotted arrows).

For consequential use cases implemented with P-V-E, once the Planner has prepared the execution plan, an automated Verifier independently checks whether the plan meets expectations. Such checks verify whether the plan sequence of subtasks logically makes sense, aligns with the provided strategic objective, and adheres to security and compliance requirements. In case the Verifier identifies problems, it sends the plan on to a Refiner that adjusts the plan accordingly and brings it in line before handing subtasks over to the Executor. The validation process could be repeated, by having the Verifier test the refined plan first.

In especially high stakes scenarios, the plan should be verified by the user (HITL) before the hand-off to the Executor. That should certainly be done for any use cases with potential harm to human dignity, rights or life which in addition may realistically require a second human approver. HITL can also avoid the Verifier and Refiner getting stuck in a verification and plan refinement loop and no agreement can be reached within a limited number of tries.

 

Quis Custodiet Ipsos Agentes? (Who Will Guard the Agents Themselves?)

With agents observing each other in this manner, utilizing various LLMs, statistical engines, or deterministic rule sets, and incorporating HITL, the likelihood of catastrophic emergent misalignment is significantly minimized. Backed by different methods, these agents are unlikely to fail or deceive in the same way. Even if the Planner implemented with a sophisticated reasoning model came up with a ‚Äúpaperclip maximizer‚Äù plan, the Verifier and HITL have an opportunity to catch it, before it is executed. Meanwhile, by providing the Executor with subtasks one-by-one, it can‚Äôt ‚Äúlook ahead‚Äù and abuse an agent or tool out of sequence.

This segregation of duties and intermediation of user requests across different agents makes agentic AI systems more resilient to misalignment. Auditable control points for Governance, Risk, and Compliance (GRC), managed execution flow, and least privileged access control on task level further strengthen that. The quartet of Planner, Executor, Verifier and Refiner keep each other in check, at critical junctions supplemented by HITL, including any potential four-eye review and approval. As the old IBM quote goes, ‚ÄúA computer can never be held accountable, therefore a computer must never make a management decision‚Äù. User-Involved Execution, where necessary extended with User-Involved Planning, centers human oversight and accountability.

 

Conclusion

Following the P-t-E pattern, agents are provided with limited trust, limited knowledge, and limited autonomy. Agents retain individual creativity while balancing each other out, rather than amplifying their potential for misaligned, deceptive and other undesirable behavior. Agentic AI systems designed along this pattern will behave more predictably and be easier to audit, without compromising their ability to complete complex workflows and objectives for their users.  

In the first part of the series, we discussed how difficult it is to control unsupervised agents. The second part offered a way to limit agent autonomy through least privilege access control. However, until part 3 we lacked an approach to enforce such controls through intermediation and agents-watching-agents. In this final part, we extended the P-t-E pattern with additional automated and human validation for higher risk use cases. Together, we hope they outline key new threats to consider in developing agentic AI systems, and how to guard against them.

 

More Information

  • When Thinking LLMs Lie: Unveiling the Strategic Deception in Representations of Reasoning Models (Arxiv, June 2025)
  • AI Lovers Grieve Loss of ChatGPT‚Äôs Old Model: ‚ÄòLike Saying Goodbye To Someone I Know‚Äô (The Guardian, August 2025)
  • Nuclear Deployed: Analyzing Catastrophic Risks in Decision-making of Autonomous LLM Agents (ACL Anthology, July 2025)
  • Architecting Resilient LLM Agents: A Guide to Secure Plan-then-Execute Implementations, Ron F. Del Rosario, Klaudia Krawiecka, Christian Schroeder de Witt (ArXiv, Sep 2025)
  • ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs Not What We Agreed!‚Äù ‚Äì Repudiation and Agentic AI Threat Modeling (SAP Community)
  • Limiting Agent Autonomy ‚Äì Least Privilege and Tool Access for Agentic AI Systems (SAP Community)
  • Plan-then-Execute ‚Äì An Architectural Pattern for Responsible Agentic AI (SAP Community)

entry.title: GRC Tuesdays: What‚Äôs New in SAP solutions for Three Lines, Q3 2025 to Q4 2025
entry.content:
It‚Äôs the end of what has been a busy year for SAP‚Äôs GRC Product Management and Development teams. And I am sure wouldn‚Äôt have missed that a lot of the focus has gone into the preparation of the SAP GRC for SAP HANA 1.0 (SAP GRC 2026) version.

But the teams have also worked diligently on continuously providing enhancements to the existing solutions so that you don‚Äôt have to wait to benefit from multiple innovations.

In this blog, I have selected a few recently delivered capabilities in SAP solutions for Three Lines of Defense available through the latest Support Packages (SP26 and SP27) that I thought would be of interest. But I have also listed at this bottom of this blog the direct links to the dedicated sections of the Help Portal where you will not only find much more detailed information but also many other enhancements that I haven‚Äôt included below. So, feel free to have a look and browse further!

 

Focus on SAP Process Control for Internal Control and Compliance

 

Monitoring CCM adequacy

 

For the reporting Monitoring Business Rules and Connectors, users can now compare control frequency and job frequency:

o   Control with no frequency shows red icon

o   Control with no job shows red icon

o   Control or job with customized frequency shows yellow icon

o   Control frequency higher than job frequency shows yellow icon

o   Control frequency equalling to job frequency shows green icon

o   Control frequency lower than job frequency shows green icon

Control with no frequency

Control with no Jobs

Control with recurring frequency

Control with customized frequency

 

 

Removal of the 100-character limit for attachment

 

Previously, when adding a file to Attachments and Links via option "Add Files" there was a technical limit of 100 characters on the filename length. This limitation on the filename length has been removed.

 

Focus on SAP Risk Management for Enterprise and Operational Risk Management

 

Response Grouping

 

It's now possible to group multiple responses together for a single risk and define how their mitigation values should be taken over for the analysis calculation. To achieve this, users can mark multiple responses and put them into a group and define what logic should be used to calculate the mitigation values. Risk analysis calculation automatically considers this grouping accordingly.

The aggregation of the grouped responses includes:

o   Maximum mitigation value from the grouped responses

o   Minimum mitigation value from the grouped responses

o   Average mitigation value from the grouped responses

 

 

 

 

Business Impact Analysis (BIA) monitoring

 

 

Following the introduction of the Business Impact Analysis capability in SAP Risk Management last year (cf. prior GRC Tuesdays blog), 2 new reports have been added to help users monitor business impact analysis:

o   Business Impact Analysis

o   BIA Survey Results

These can be accessed in the ‚ÄúRisks and Opportunities‚Äù section of the ‚ÄúReports and Analytics‚Äù work center.

 

Focus on SAP Audit Management for Independent Assurance

 

Rolling and non-rolling audit plans

 

When creating a new audit plan, auditors can now select from the two audit plan types: ‚ÄúRolling‚Äù and ‚ÄúNon-rolling‚Äù. A rolling audit plan allows users to create a successor audit plan by copying the original audit plan. The successor plan, or the new audit plan, carries forward the risks, auditable items, and unfinished audits from the original audit plan. Auditors can adjust the goals, scope, and timeline of the new audit plan and continue the unfinished audits.

 

A non-rolling audit plan is a standalone plan that does not automatically carry forward risks, auditable items, or unfinished audits to any future audit plans. Each non-rolling audit plan is treated as an independent cycle, with its own defined scope, objectives, and timeline. At the conclusion of the plan, any uncompleted audits or outstanding items are not propagated to subsequent plans unless manually re-added by the auditor. This type is typically used for one-time audits, project-specific reviews, or when a clean break from prior planning cycles is desired.

 

 

 

 

Risk Matrix

 

 

Users can now maintain a risk matrix for risk analysis. With a risk matrix, the risk level is automatically determined based on the likelihood and impact. Given a likelihood level and impact level, the risk level is automatically determined against the risk matrix.

 

Referencing action plans

 

If a finding can be resolved by the action plans of other findings in the same audit, auditors can create references to those action plans, instead of re-creating the same action plans again.

 

 

Looking for more information?

 

Since I am sure this short blog won‚Äôt have answered all your questions ‚Äì and because it didn‚Äôt list all the enhancements delivered but just a selection, I would also recommend having a look at the links below:

  • What‚Äôs New in SAP Process Control
  • What‚Äôs New in SAP Risk Management
  • What‚Äôs New in SAP Audit Management

Finally, in case you still want to hear more about it, we‚Äôll have a dedicated session during next year‚Äôs SAP for Internal Controls, Compliance and Risk Management Conference in March 2026 in Amsterdam. Join us on site to learn more!

I look forward to reading your thoughts and comments on this blog.

And if you are interested in learning more about SAP solutions for Governance, Risk, and Compliance, feel free to fill-in the demo request form!

entry.title: Building Resilient Enterprises: SAP‚Äôs Security Gains from Microsoft Defender for Cloud
entry.content:
By Sven Frank, Cyber Security Architect IAM & Zero Trust (SAP), Martin Pankraz, Principal Product Manager SAP Integration and Security (Microsoft), Amos Wendorff, Cyber Security Data Governance Lead

 

üö®The 3 PM Friday Security Crisis: Why Human-Centered Security Matters

Picture this: It's 3 PM on a Friday, and your development team just discovered a critical production issue affecting thousands of customers. A major client demo is scheduled for Monday morning, and your lead developer needs to spin up additional Azure resources immediately to implement a hotfix. The standard security approval process typically takes 48 hours.

‚ö†Ô∏èThe Dangerous Moment: In this high-pressure situation, it's tempting to take shortcuts‚Äîopening broader network access than necessary, using shared service accounts, or bypassing security scanning protocols. "We'll fix it properly after the crisis," becomes the dangerous refrain that can turn a temporary workaround into a permanent vulnerability.

üõ°Ô∏è The SAP Secure-by-Default Philosophy

At SAP, securing our Microsoft Azure landscapes extends beyond technology alone. We face tight deadlines and pressure to complete projects quickly, which can challenge maintaining strong security practices. That's why our secure-by-default approach‚Äîclosing unnecessary ports, phasing out legacy authentication, and enforcing automated policies with thorough identity management‚Äîis designed to support everyone in staying secure, even when time is limited.

‚ö°Speed AND Security, Not Speed OR Security

When our developer can provision resources through pre-configured, security-hardened templates with just a few clicks, we eliminate the false choice between speed and security. Equally important is fostering a security-conscious mindset throughout our teams, grounded in continuous learning and constructive accountability. Through consistent knowledge-sharing sessions, we ensure alignment across the organization.

üîóBridging Security and Architecture: A Real-World Challenge

But here's where it gets more complex. Fast-forward to Monday morning‚Äîthe crisis is resolved, but now our Enterprise Architecture team discovers something concerning. During the weekend sprint, three different teams independently deployed similar cloud applications to solve related problems. Each believed they were following secure practices, but collectively, they've created an unmanaged sprawl of SaaS applications across our landscape.

The traditional scenario: Our security team knows these applications exist and can assess their individual risk profiles through Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps. Meanwhile, our enterprise architects are mapping our application portfolio in SAP LeanIX, trying to understand capability gaps and technology dependencies. In most enterprises, IT security and enterprise architecture are two critical disciplines, each with their own priorities, tools, and perspectives. One is laser-focused on threat detection, compliance, and access control. The other is mapping capabilities, rationalizing applications, and shaping long-term IT strategy.
But what if these two worlds could work together seamlessly?

 

üéØThe Power of Integration: SAP #LeanIX + Microsoft Defender for Cloud App

At SAP, we've implemented an integration between SAP LeanIX and Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps that transforms how we approach secure and compliant software usage. With this integration, you can pull application usage and risk data from Defender for Cloud Apps directly into SAP LeanIX. That means: ... You're no longer just identifying what's out there - you're aligning it with your architecture strategy. This turns ad-hoc discovery into intentional governance.

üîçReal-Time Visibility Meets Strategic Planning

Applications are added to Cloud Apps in MS Defender when someone accesses a cloud application through their browser, which could lead to a significant number of discovered applications. This continuous discovery feeds directly into our LeanIX environment, where our enterprise architects can immediately see:

  • Risk-aligned Architecture Decisions: Security risk scores from Defender for Cloud Apps appear alongside capability mappings in LeanIX, enabling architects to make informed decisions about application rationalization
  • Compliance-Driven Portfolio Management: Applications flagged for compliance issues in Defender are automatically highlighted in our architecture views, allowing us to prioritize remediation based on business impact
  • Usage-Based Capability Planning: Real usage data helps identify which applications are truly critical versus those that can be consolidated or retired

üöÄFrom Reactive Discovery to Proactive Governance

This integration fosters collaboration between two personas that often operate in parallel but rarely intersect. With Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps and SAP LeanIX, they do - bringing security and architecture into a shared conversation around risk, capability, and value.

Kahoot is an example of an in-house approved application, in the terminology of Defender for Cloud Apps a sanctioned application. This allows the Enterprise Architect to make clear, data-driven decisions when harmonizing tools, eliminating guesswork and ensuring alignment across the organization.

If you want to learn more about LeanIX and Defender for Cloud Apps, have a look here.
This blog post was co-authored by @Michelle10 

 

üåäThe Ripple Effect of Integrated Security / Final Part

This comprehensive strategy enables us to effectively protect our environments and maintain the highest security standards across our SAP landscapes in Azure - even when the pressure is on.

Ultimately, our customers and partners benefit directly from these security practices, as they translate into more robust, reliable, and trustworthy SAP solutions. The secure-by-default principles and security-conscious culture that protect our Azure environments become foundational elements when organizations implement our products - creating a ripple effect that strengthens security across the broader ecosystem.

entry.title: GRC Tuesdays: What's New in SAP Risk and Assurance Management, Q4 2025
entry.content:
As I am sure you are already well aware, if you want to be amongst the first to know what is new within SAP Risk and Assurance Management, all the information is just one click away in the dedicated section of the product Help Portal.

In these GRC Tuesdays blog, we take a different angle: we don‚Äôt provide an exhaustive list, instead, we just make a focus on certain capabilities that we think can spark your interest.

Working with Claudia Behrendt and Alain-Brieuc Gall from SAP Product Management, we have decided to highlight 2 new enhancements delivered recently in SAP Risk and Assurance Management:

  • New integrated reporting dashboards in Enterprise SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)
  • Predicted Conclusions in the Issue Management and Remediation service

 

New integrated reporting dashboards in Enterprise SAP Analytics Cloud

 

By leveraging the SAP Analytics Cloud stories, users of SAP Risk and Assurance Management can significantly improve their master data compliance and risk management processes, leading to enhanced efficiency, reduced risks, and a more robust assurance framework.

To support this objective the team has released a new SAC story:

Risk & Assurance Management Cockpit

This new dashboard increases transparency for Compliance executives as it provides them with a cockpit-like experience with actionable insights derived from visual and comparative analysis of compliance data. It helps in identifying patterns, tracking performance over time, and prioritizing efforts effectively.

This comprehensive view enhances the organization‚Äôs ability to manage risks and assurance activities, ultimately leading to better compliance and operational excellence.

This SAP Analytics Cloud story includes the following visualisations:

Instant Overview

 

 

Provides an immediate snapshot of compliance issues, organized by type and status, with visual charts that display trends over time.

Efficiency Metrics

 

 

Offers insights into average issue resolution times and year-to-year analysis, helping to identify process inefficiencies.

 Comparative Analysis

 

 

Makes it easy to compare current performance and highlights long-term trends and deviations, facilitating informed decision-making.

 

Controls Compliance Dashboard

And, in case you missed the information or simply forgot about it, allow me to refresh your memory: there is already another SAC story previously available: the Controls Compliance Dashboard.

With this dashboard, users to have a granular view of their compliance posture, ensuring that all necessary controls are in place and that data integrity is maintained. It helps them identify potential risks early and taking proactive measures to mitigate them, thereby enhancing overall operational efficiency and compliance readiness.

The SAP Analytics Cloud stories in this dashboard are based on information from the controls‚Äô master data and associated run results:

Compliance Coverage

 

 

Helps to understand the compliance coverage of controls, ensuring that all critical areas are adequately monitored.

Master Data Completeness

 

 

Assesses the completeness of master data across the controls, identifying any gaps or discrepancies that need attention.

Data Hygiene

 

 

Highlights data holes and orphaned data, facilitating timely data completion or clean-up efforts to maintain accuracy and relevance.

 Complementary Insights

 

 

Complements the Fiori apps but provides additional, in-depth insights not available in the standard apps.

 Compliance Status

 

 

Offers a comprehensive view of the compliance status of controls across organizations, processes, and regulations, with dedicated KPIs.

 Failure Analysis

 

 

Shows which and how many controls fail at any given time and over time, across various dimensions, including automated and manual procedures.

 

Predicted Conclusions in the Issue Management and Remediation service

 

Shifting gear from reporting to workflows, with decision support for issues with Machine Learning, organizations can benefit from predictive model to automate decision-making and speed up issue processing. The model uses historical decisions to predict outcomes for new issues.

Compliance specialists are often faced with numerous issues raised that they need to quickly review and categorize so that they are addressed in time by relevant stakeholders.

If this is a key aspect of their role ‚Äì especially when new types of issues arise that would require expert review, many issues are quite ‚Äústandard‚Äù and decisions can be streamlined by an intelligent engine: confirm the issue and assign it for remediation or close it as a false positive.

This is precisely what this capability offers: to serve as an enabler for further automation steps for issue processing.

Based on previous manual decisions for related issues, SAP Risk and Assurance Management can generate an automated conclusion and display its level of confidence:

entry.title: GRC Tuesdays: SAP GTS Edition for SAP HANA 2025, Sneak Preview
entry.content:
Since Christmas is not far away, I think I would grant you your secret wish: get an early preview of what‚Äôs coming in SAP Global Trade Services, edition for SAP HANA 2025.

As per the Product Availability Matrix, this release is planned for this quarter so the Help Portal will be updated accordingly in time, but, if you read this blog, it‚Äôs because Santa‚Äôs helpers ‚Äì here more likely Volker Mohr from Product Management and Torsten Stolz from Engineering, have provided a sneak preview of what you can expect in this release. 

 

Planned enhancements

 

Enablement of the administrator function in SAP Fiori launchpad

A modernization of the user interface for administrators is planned by providing access to transactions using SAP Fiori launchpad. This will help increase work efficiency and enable the administrator role to be consistent with other business roles.

 

Mass maintenance of agreement-specific product properties

This enhancement will enable users to complete the maintenance of agreement-specific properties for one or multiple products at the same time in one screen, hence reducing the administrative burden and increasing information quality at the same time.

 

Maintenance of country and region of origin in inbound LTSD (technical delivery)

First technical delivery in what will further be improved with subsequent Support Packages, the maintenance of country and region of origin will allow users to maintain this information in the inbound Long Term Supplier Declaration (LTSD) at the product level.

 

New SAP Fiori app ‚ÄúManage Partners ‚Äì SPL Screening‚Äù

The previous app ‚ÄúManage Blocked Business Partners‚Äù will be deprecated and a new Fiori app ‚ÄúManage Partners ‚Äì SPL* Screening‚Äù will enable users to process all business partners, whether they are blocked or released.

This ensures that organizations can also manage business partners which were released before and block them again or add them to positive or negative lists.

In this app, the user will be able to easily navigate among screening results of different business partners.

* SPL: Sanctioned Party Lists

 

Updates to screening capabilities of the sanctioned party list

 

The planned enhancement of the screening capabilities of the sanctioned party list will help improve compliance with international regulations and ensure frictionless international trade processes by allowing ‚Äúblock by association‚Äù between a business partner and bank master data.

To achieve this the following capabilities will be added:

  • Transferring SWIFT/bank identifier codes (BICs) and benefit-in-kind (BIK) codes of bank master data from the feeder system to SAP GTS
  • Transferring a relationship between business partners and banks during the transfer of customers, vendors, and employees from the feeder system and storing the relationship in SAP GTS
  • Managing of additional addresses of account holders in the bank details in business partner master data
  • Screening of bank master data with related IDs in SAP GTS
  • Screening of customers and vendors with associated bank

 

Integration with decentralized advanced shipping and receiving processes

 

Integration of SAP Global Trade Services (SAP GTS) with support for the outbound processes of advanced shipping and receiving in a decentralized extended warehouse management and transportation management landscape for trade compliance and customs management will increase efficiency with integration of the decentralized scenario for outbound freight management supported by SAP GTS. This enhancement will include:

  • Compliance check for the outbound freight unit and freight order
  • Export declaration based on the freight order

  

Railway bill of lading 

 

The Customs Waybill for Rail feature ensures compliance with U.S. Customs requirements for rail shipments by accurately transmitting waybill data. The feature addresses complexities in coordinating freight forwarders, carriers, and BOL issuers for rail cargo. Overall, it streamlines rail logistics in the context of SAP GTS processes for Importation and US Free Trade Zone processes with customs authorities.

 

Automated Partnering Government Agency (US PGA) change messaging

 

The CA/CC messages supports the changes of PGA Data of a declaration even after no change to the declaration itself is allowed any longer. The system automatically detects the changed PGA data after being changed in the declaration and transmits these to US CBP.  By this you can ensure to compliantly close all PGA activities even after customs declaration fixation.

 

Legal changes

 

And of course, in addition to the functional and technical enhancements, legal changes are also planned.

These can be found in the Regulatory Change Manager which provides timely information on upcoming regulatory changes that can affect SAP products. It offers a comprehensive and well-organized collection of information, and filters by product. To focus only on updates relevant for SAP GTS for instance.

This Regulatory Change Manager service can be accessed directly from the SAP For Me portal, under the Services & Support dashboard in the sidebar.

 

Be the first to know!

 

They say that information is power, so be the first to know about the details of any enhancement in SAP Global Trade Services, edition for HANA via the dedicated SAP Help Portal Page:

This page consolidates delta information about all functions of this product that are new, changed, or deleted not only for the latest version, but also all previous updates, and will be updated for SAP GTS, edition for SAP HANA 2025 in due time.
